comments.commentBody: Lung cancer is on the rise and no smoking signs are appearing in public setting including the high school, but your quote of 7% gov’t revenue is very telling; what is needed is cancer among those current in power. They have the benefit of filtered air in work place and homes compared with others. Attend a social event and cigarettes are passed out at the door and offered again on the dining table. When introduced to a new acquaintance a man will be offered cigarette by another; deep in the social milieu. But my American father smoked 2 packs a day (and died young) and it was an American thing for far too long, as you well know in N.C.. Maybe China can change.

Hundreds of thousands, probably millions, of Chinese professionals have studied abroad. They know the United States, Canada, Europe and Australia and they often travel to these countries on vacation. It is impossible to believe that they or their families could take seriously a statement like "The first option for hostile forces infiltrating us is our education system." As for "devilish claws", they would laugh. The government is clinging to this kind of thing because its moral authority is so low, but only the uninformed would believe it.

I remember my high school years in state college high in penn. The american students and chinese students quickly developed a poisonous relationship: the chinese students told me americans really hate china and is trying to dismantle their country by assisting dissidents and dalai lama. And yet the west still denies subverting china, how ironic.
Or the Education Minister is a lightweight trying to hang on in his perceived concept of "what is expected now."

Save from moving it from impoverishment to world’s second highest GNP, with a little help from Wall St.
What Trump can do with help from a Rep. Congress we will know soon enough.
Global warmiing is worth concern for those worry about earths fut

It is time for Mongolia to rejoin China.

The CIA facts show a 2011 population of 3.13 million, and a 2010 GDP of $6.125 billion.

Mongolia is landlocked (so what if it has lots of minerals, they can't be airfreighted out); and it has terrible management. Average household income is like $2,000-3,000 a year. If Beijing goes in with an invitation for Mongolia to join a Federated Union, by offering US$50,000 (this is close to a lifetime of current income per family) upfront per head (which comes to US$160 Billion), commitment to invest another US$200 Billion for development, plus setting up a trust fund that pays 3% of all mineral extractions to the natives, now that'd be something to talk about.

Local politics would still be left to the locals. The new money and new spendable wealth would most likely all be spent locally and regionally, and it would further benefit growth to the regional economies.

Beats buying stocks in Blackstone or Goldman Sachs.

It is quite unlikely that this can be accomplished by 2030. But contingent plans should be in place.

Yes, my friend. The Mongols surely aspire to what happened to the Tibetans and Uighurs: no freedom of movement, religion and speech. Massive invasion of Hans who take over the economy and local politics. Massive destruction of the environment, pollution and militarization. Yes, living under the Chinese yoke must surely be something to look for.
As depressing as the political situation here in the U.S. has become, it is nothing compared to the ongoing plight of Tibet. My heart goes out to these kind, unassuming people.
makes China look small and petty
Sad. The Dalai Lama is cool. China is not.

Congratulations to NYT for highlighting and drawing attention to a part of the world forgotten and ignored by the media. In a world riven by political unrest, violence, religious intolerance, wanton destruction of ancient cultures, humanitarian crises and more.... The Dalai Lama represents a breath of pristine thinking. He is both a spiritual leader and by his example a concept that is rapidly fading away from the international scene. Let us hope Mongolia's capitulation to Chinese pressure will not end up like Tibet's own sad saga of a half century and more ago. As we ring in the New a Year stories such as this are heartening. They remind us there are still places on earth where countries are trying hard to cling to their heritage which are based on belief systems drawn from sources that differ from Abrahmic definitions of dogmatic religions and Marxist doctrines of hegemony. The tolerance inherent in such thinking that the Dalai Lama inspires and propagates offers us a glimmer of hope as we ring in the New Year.

Mongolia is currently in an economic recession.  China also increased import taxes on goods from Mongolia immediately after the Dalai Lama's visit this time.  Minerals being a main export in this landlocked country, this must have sent a subtle but strong message to the Mongolian government.

Every sentient being is endowed with Buddha nature and has the capacity to become a Buddha.  Awakening to your true nature does not require the Dali Lama to reincarnate.  The dharma wheel will continue to turn.  Peace and happiness to all.
Facts?
It's a sad sign of China's never-ending insecurity that the travels of an elderly holy man inspire such terror and rage amongst the Communist dictators of Beijing.
I think that someone whose main mission is an ocean of wisdom, should be given wide latitude in their freedoms to teach and to travel

The Chinese have been busy in 2016, imprisoning Tibetans, razing Tibetan monasteries and harassing governments who ddare to acknowledge the wisdom and inner beauty of one of the most impressive spiritual leaders of our time.

One cannot really blame the Mongolian government for trading their politics for loan guarantees. After all, this will do nothing to change the affection and respect the Mongolian people have for HH the Dala Lama, nor the distaste we all have for Chinese bullying.

Despite leaders who lust for power and use it to amass more wealth and power for themselves and their cronies, the hearts of the people of this world will always recognize and prize Goodness.

"Kindness is my religion," the Dalai Lama has said.

It is interesting to contemplate what kind of person would be threatened by someone like that.

May 2017 be the year when good, caring women, men and children in every country on the planet will rise up and find their strength in a global community of kindness.
Hopefully, Mongolia will honor its historic ties to Tibet and the Dalai Lama, and not succumb to the bully-boy racist Han tactics of the CCP.

The best thing the Dalai Lama can do is to reaffirm that he will be the last Dalai Lama. China is extremely unhappy about the prospect because it will take away a political tool. More important to Buddhism is that it will put an end to a speculative system of power inheritance that deviated from the original teachings of the Buddha. By the end of his life, the Buddha was asked to appoint a successor to lead his followers. The Buddha absolutely rejected the idea. He said that his teaching itself together with the set of monastic code of conduct are sufficient as a guide for all Buddhists. For centuries in India and elsewhere it prevented the pitfall of power struggle that is common in other religions.

What a pity that ideological indoctrination is compulsory for young Chinese kids, but not in the least surprising in light of the current administration's obsession with stability. There is a glaring discrepancy between the government drive to transform China into a leading global innovator, and the requirement of monochromatic thinking among its intellectual class. Creativity comes from those who think differently, who don't conform to instructional norms, and not from those who test well on conventional exams. Herein lies the Chinese conundrum.

As a parent I am extremely wary of our public schools using IB as a curriculum. No country should allow another country to develop their school curriculum. Even in Switzerland, where IB is developed, only a handful of international schools use this curriculum. Virtually no other country adopt IB as a PUBLIC school curriculum except in the US. We are the new cash cow for IB.

The "forward thinking" leftist open borderists now running our school system love IB. It's their globalist dream come true. A curriculum that truly promotes the "One World" view. 11th grade US history is replaced by "History of the Americas". English Lit studies translated work from Asian and African countries rather than Shakespeare or Dickens. US children don't even know their own country's history. 70+ US universities including George Washington University now do not even require a single US history course to graduate as a History major.

The left who's been dominating our education system are doing everything they can to kill off the concept of nation states, to promote their grand vision of a "global village" complete with open borders and multiculturalism, and IB is their weapon of choice. Schools in Houston are now offering IB starting in elementary school. Start the brainwashing from as young as possible. Our district now wants to introduce "social studies" to elementary school, just like what the Chinese are doing in this article.

No worries. We are heading for convergence. Our schools in the US from K-college have been teaching kids the evil of inequality and emphasizing the glory of equality, as in achieving equal outcome, which is the basis of Communism.

Kids today are no longer taught the fall of the Soviet Union and its causes. Equality is glorified in the form of Socialism. Of course, as we all know the only difference between Socialism and Communism is elections, one has the pretense of democracy, the other simply does away with it as it's no longer necessary when everyone depends on the state for livelihood.

Judging from the reaction of the butt hurt generation on the result of this election, I'd say our Indoctrination I mean Education System has been doing such a fine job with the brainwashing of our youth the past 4 decades there is no longer a need for Socialism, we are ready to go straight to Communism. Why bother with elections when only one outcome is acceptable?

I don't believe that the conflict is between Western and Chinese values. The very fact that so many Chinese are chafing under compulsory political education (or ignoring it), and that so many Chinese parents are anxious for their kids to get out of that system, shows that at least some of the "Western" values feared by the party leadership are more universal than they think. This is not say that there are no "Chinese" values worth preserving, such as dedication to family. But rigidly prescribing the boundaries of acceptable thought cannot, and should not, work.
Not a pip? Odd that, I live a rural Northern California town, and I have read of this movie.
The crossword app clue for 3D says "Capital of Iran", yet the answer is the currency of Iran (rial). That messed me up!

"The rules would not apply to international schools set up primarily to educate foreign students."

The takeaway from this whole brouhaha, of course, is the definition of "foreign students." The Chinese government doesn't and won't regulate education for foreigners, but it'll be most interesting to see how those Chinese who have money to finagle their kids into international schools are going to be yielded, or not. And they certainly can't hide behind those expensive "private schools."

Would the next step of the government be more regulation for international schools operating in the country to ask for foreign citizenship proof before they enroll a student? That would be a logical next-step to put up the wall between genuine "foreign students" from those "local students" with rich parents.

Technically there is already a rule regarding that. However, like everything in China, exceptions are always made. The party secretary for education in my area's child goes to an International School - what does that tell you about the double standard?

At my current school what we noticed was A LOT of enrollments in early primary have kids with western passports but they are 100% Chinese. That's how the parents get around the rules.

Also, there are A LOT of kids that after grade 9 in the Chinese system that move to International or private schools because the government is no longer regulating them.

I just returned from 2 years of teaching in China. Students who cannot present a non-Chinese passport may not enroll in real international schools, so yes, they are already asking for proof of foreign citizenship.
You would be better served to read up on Chinese history before you make a comment like yours (which shows your lack of understanding of that country, their history, and culture).
